content.raw: Create a `std::unique_ptr` to your private data containing the adiabatic power and create accessors for it.
content.html: Create a std::unique_ptr to your private data containing the adiabatic power and create accessors for it.

content.raw: We internally discussed how to use opaque pointers with inheritance recently. We agreed to make `dataPtr` always private. In your case  `AdiabaticAtmospherePrivate` shouldn't inherit from any other class. If you need to access the members of the base class in your derived classes you can use the function accessors.
content.html: We internally discussed how to use opaque pointers with inheritance recently. We agreed to make dataPtr always private. In your case AdiabaticAtmospherePrivate shouldn't inherit from any other class. If you need to access the members of the base class in your derived classes you can use the function accessors.

content.raw:
Shouldn't be clear if the key matches the related member variable and accessor? E.g.: `temperatureSL` instead of `temperature`, `pressureSL` instead of `pressure`, etc.

Maybe there's a reason for that but it seems that you're asking for all these parameters at sea level. Otherwise I believe you would need an extra parameter for the altitude.
content.html:
Shouldn't be clear if the key matches the related member variable and accessor? E.g.: temperatureSL instead of temperature, pressureSL instead of pressure, etc.

Maybe there's a reason for that but it seems that you're asking for all these parameters at sea level. Otherwise I believe you would need an extra parameter for the altitude.

content.raw: I believe these elements are optional in an Atmosphere SDF block. Shouldn't we check if the element exists before reading it?
content.html: I believe these elements are optional in an Atmosphere SDF block. Shouldn't we check if the element exists before reading it?

content.raw: I think you don't need any of these `Reset()` calls in the destructor.
content.html: I think you don't need any of these Reset() calls in the destructor.

content.raw: Add the `#include` for the types used in this file.
content.html: Add the #include for the types used in this file.

content.raw:
It seems that there are two ways of accessing to the atmosphere parameters:

* `Param()`/`SetParam()`.
* Specific accessors. E.g.: `Temperature()`/`SetTemperature()`.

Is there any reason for keeping both options public?
content.html:
It seems that there are two ways of accessing to the atmosphere parameters:

  • Param()/SetParam().
  • Specific accessors. E.g.: Temperature()/SetTemperature().

Is there any reason for keeping both options public?

content.raw: I don't think this `#include` is needed.

update.description:
This pull request provides a base class Atmosphere and a derived class AdiabaticAtmosphere that implements an adiabatic atmosphere model.

The global atmosphere parameters are defined in the SDF file, they consist of the temperature, pressure, mass density, and temperature gradient at sea level. The Atmosphere class is instantiated once during World initialization. A plugin can access the Atmosphere singleton with ```World::Atmosphere()``` and query its values at different altitudes. For now, only one type of atmosphere model is available: the adiabatic atmosphere model.

If it gets accepted, this feature would require a new optional section in the world SDF file (see related pull request [#241](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/241/new-element/diff)):

```
#!xml
<world name="default">
  <atmosphere name="default" type="adiabatic">
    <temperature>288.15</temperature> <!-- Temperature at sea level in kelvins -->
    <pressure>101325</pressure> <!-- Pressure at sea level in pascals -->
    <mass_density>1.225</mass_density> <!-- Mass density of the air at sea level in kg/m^3 -->
    <temperature_gradient>-0.0065</temperature_gradient> <!-- Temperature gradient with respect to increasing altitude at sea level in units of K/m -->
  </atmosphere>
</world>
```

At the client side, the atmosphere parameters are displayed in the property tree browser and can be changed dynamically.
update.title: Atmosphere model

content.raw: Change to `gzerr << "Unable to create atmosphere model\n"`
